chapter: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: Which of the following is not true regarding obstetric cholestasis?

options.C: Pruritus usually develops in the third trimester

questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: A woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents with severe itching over her palms and soles for 2weeks. She gives a history of similar complaints in her last pregnancy. On examination, she isicteric. Which of the following is the preferred investigation to diagnose this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical picture is suggestive of cholestasis in pregnancy. Serum bile acid is the earliestand most consistent parameter to increase in obstetric cholestasis.Serum cholic acid is preferred compared to serum chenodeoxycholic acid.Although serum bile acid increases after meals it is still considered an important investigationamong women with obstetric cholestasis. This is because serum bile acid levels remainsignificantly elevated in women with obstetric cholestasis in comparison to pregnant womenwithout it.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: A food critic at 32 weeks of gestation presents with nausea and mild right upper abdominalpain. She also gives a history of itching over palms and soles for 2 weeks. On examination,she is icteric. Investigations done are shown below. What is the preferred treatment in thiscondition?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of obstetric cholestasis. Ursodeoxycholic acid is the drug of choicein obstetric cholestasis.It relieves pruritus, lowers bile acid and serum enzyme levels (like SGOT, ALP). It may also reducecertain neonatal complications such as preterm birth, fetal distress, and respiratory distresssyndrome.Antihistamines and topical emollients may provide some relief.Cholestyramine causes decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, which leads to vitamin Kdeficiency. Fetal coagulopathy may develop, which may lead to intracranial hemorrhage andstillbirth, and therefore it is not preferred.DisorderCholestasis of pregnancyAcute fatty liver of pregnancyHepatitis
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: 533Which of the following features are not likely to be seen in a patient with acute fatty liver ofpregnancy?
questions.explanation: AST (SGOT)U/LBilirubin (mg/dL)Up to 2001-5200-8004-102000+5-20542Hyperglycemia, hypercholesterolemia, and thrombocytosis are not likely to be seen in acute fattyliver of pregnancy (AFLP).Clinical features of AFLP include:• Persistent nausea and vomiting•.Progressive jaundiceHypoglycemia• Hypertension• Proteinuria• Edema•••Thrombocytopenia• Moderate to severe liver dysfunction - manifested by:⚫ Hypofibrinogenemia• Hypoalbuminemia• Hypocholesterolemia•Prolonged clotting time.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: A woman at 37 weeks of gestation with icterus, nausea, and yellowish discoloration of urinehas abnormal liver function tests. She is suspected to have acute fatty liver of pregnancy.Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.D: Occurs due to heterozygous defect for fatty acid oxidation

questions.explanation: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is more commonly associated with male fetuses and notfemale fetuses.AFLP is a rare, potentially fatal complication also known as acute fatty metamorphosis or acuteyellow atrophy. It is more common in the third trimester. It is due to a defect in thelong-chain-3-hydroxy acyl-CoA-dehydrogenase (LCHAD) pathway.It is also associated with:• First pregnancy - uncommon in subsequent pregnancies.• Maternal obesity.• Multiple pregnanciesInvestigations:• Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised.•Hemolysis with coagulopathy:• Decreased platelets and fibrinogen• Elevated d-dimers and prothrombin time.•Biopsy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration.The definitive management of AFLP is rapid delivery of the fetus and supportive care. Hepaticdysfunction usually normalizes within a week of delivery.543
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: Which of the following will not increase the risk for urinary tract infection in pregnantwomen?
questions.explanation: Hypertension is not a risk factor for urinary infections in pregnancy.Risk factors for urinary infections in pregnancy include:•• Vesicoureteric reflux of pregnancy•Urinary retention•Diabetes in pregnancy•Sickle cell anemia
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: A G3P2 lady at 13 weeks of gestation presented for a regular antenatal checkup. A urineroutine revealed the presence of 2,00,000 gram-negative bacilli/mL. Repeat urinalysisshowed the following results. Which of the following is not true about this condition?

options.A: Incidence is similar to that in non pregnant women
options.B: It is higher in people with sickle cell trait
options.C: Antibiotic therapy is required only if symptoms develop534
options.D: There is risk of developing chronic renal lesions

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of asymptomatic bacteriuria. Antibiotic therapy should begiven regardless of the symptoms.Asymptomatic bacteriuria refers to persistent, actively multiplying bacteria within the urinarytract in asymptomatic women.Organisms that cause urinary infections are those from the normal perineal flora. The mostcommon causative agent is E.coli. Others include Klebsiella, and Proteus.Incidence is similar to that in non-pregnant women. Prevalence depends on parity (more in higherparity), race, socioeconomic status (more in low SES).It is more common in patients with sickle cell anemia/trait, diabetes. There is a high risk ofdeveloping chronic renal lesions in later life.It is also associated with:••⚫ Hypertension• Anemia•⚫ Premature labor• Intrauterine growth retardation•Urinary tract abnormalities in recurrent cases.Diagnostic criteria:• A positive bacterial count of the same species - over 1,00,000/mL•Organisms in midstream clean-catch specimen of urine on two occasions•No symptoms of urinary infectionTreatment:• Single-dose therapy - Amoxicillin 3g, Nitrofurantoin 200mg•Regular 10-14 days therapy - Amoxicillin, Nitrofurantoin, Cephalexin, or Amoxiclav544• Recurrent cases need to be treated until delivery with prophylactic doses.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: A woman presented to the clinic with severe lower abdominal pain and dysuria at 28 weeks ofgestation. Suprapubic tenderness was noted on palpation. Urine examination revealed pyuriawith microscopic hematuria. All of the following can be used to treat this condition except?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystitis. Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone antibiotic, iscontraindicated in pregnancy as it causes cartilage and bone defects in the fetus.Antibiotics are used for treating cystitis in pregnancy.Antibiotics safe in pregnancy include:• Penicillin group•Cephalosporins⚫ Erythromycin•Metronidazole (except in the 1st trimester)Antibiotics unsafe in pregnancy include:••TetracyclineAminoglycoside• Chloramphenicol•Metronidazole(in the first trimester)• Fluoroquinolones
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: Which stage of pregnancy is most often complicated by acute pyelonephritis?
questions.explanation: Acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy most often complicates 2nd trimester of pregnancy.Acute pyelonephritis occurs more commonly in those with preexisting renal disease. It is causedby E. coli >> Streptococcus sp., S.aureus > Enterobacter, Klebsiella sp.Clinical features include:• Fever with chills• Loin pain•Vomiting• Right-sided renal angle tendernessPatients may develop acute respiratory distress syndrome due to endotoxin-mediated alveolarinjury. Hemolysis can also occur due to endotoxins, leading to anemia.Treatment includes intravenous fluids with antibiotics.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: Which of the following congenital infections are associated with the triad of Gregg in aneonate?
questions.explanation: 545Triad of Gregg is seen in a neonate infected congenitally with rubella virus. The features include:• Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)• Cataract•Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL)Other infections which cause congenital malformations are:OrganisEffectmToxopla Hydro/microcephaly, convulssmaVaricellaions, chorioretinitis, cerebralcalcificationSkin scarring, hypoplastic limbs, eye defects, microcephalyParvovir Non-immune hydropsusSyphilisHutchinson's triad:Interstitia1 keratitis Hutchinson's teethEighth nerve deafness
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about toxoplasmosis in pregnancy?

options.A: Maximum transmission and damage in 1st trimester
options.B: Maximum transmission in 1st trimester and maximum damage in 3rd trimester535
options.C: Maximum damage in 1st trimester and maximum transmission in 3rd trimester
options.D: Maximum transmission and damage in 3rd trimester

questions.explanation: Toxoplasmosis causes maximal complications in 1st trimester and is maximally transmitted in the3rd trimester.This is because the risk of transmission increases and the risk of damage decreases as pregnancyprogresses further.Clinical features of affected neonates include:Hydrocephalus or microcephaly•Chorioretinitis• Intracranial calcifications• Convulsions• Low birthweight••HepatosplenomegalyJaundice• Anemia
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: A woman presents for a regular antenatal check-up at 12 weeks of gestation. She works at arescue center that held an adoption drive for cats a few weeks ago. On examination, mildcervical lymphadenopathy is noted. Sabin-Feldman dye test is positive. Which of thefollowing will be used to treat this condition?
questions.explanation: 546The given scenario points to a diagnosis of maternal toxoplasmosis. It is treated using spiramycin.Pyrimethamine-sulfonamide is used when fetal infections are confirmed. It should be avoided inthe first trimester.Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii. Cats are definitive hosts. It can be transmitted tohumans either by ingestion of raw or inadequately cooked infected meat or by ingestion of oocystsvia exposure to cat litter or soil.Acute infection is diagnosed either by the presence of IgG and IgM antibodies or by a four-foldincrease in paired specimens 4 weeks apart.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: A per-vaginal examination performed on a lady in labor reveals multiple painful tiny vesicularulcers over the vulva and vaginal walls. A slide showing the microscopic findings is givenbelow. What is the best step in the management of delivery in this patient?

options.C: Give tocolytics and treat the infection

questions.explanation: Painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy are suggestive of herpes virusinfection. The cytological image showing multinucleate giant cells, Tzanck cells confirms thediagnosis of HSV. The best step in the management of delivery in this patient is a cesareansection.Herpes infection in the newborn may occur during birth, particularly if the mother has genitallesions due to HSV-2. In such cases, a cesarean section may prevent neonatal infection.Tzanck smearThree multinucleated giant cells are seen in the center.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: In a pregnant woman with herpes simplex infection, the risk of transmission to the fetus willbe maximum during which stage of the pregnancy?
questions.explanation: The maximum risk of HSV transmission from mother to child is during labor. This is due to theshedding of the virus from an active infection in the genital tract during delivery.HSV is a sexually transmitted infection. There is a higher risk of transmission during primaryinfections than with recurrences. Reactivations are less severe.Cesarean delivery reduces the risk of vertical transmission during labor and is indicated in:547• Cases of active genital lesions - both primary and recurrent• Prodromal symptoms - like vulval itching or burningSuspicious lesions should be sent for PCR testing or culture. Antiviral treatment with acyclovirshould be given if found positive.Women without active genital lesions, without symptoms, or those with active lesions innon-genital areas can undergo normal labor and delivery.Management of HSV infection during pregnancy:••Primary or recurrent infections during pregnancy - Oral acyclovir or valacyclovirSevere or disseminated infection - IV acyclovir followed by oral acyclovirPain relief Oral analgesics or topical anesthetics-• Urinary retention - catheterization.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: The risk of fetal varicella syndrome is maximum when the mother is infected between
questions.explanation: The risk of developing fetal varicella syndrome (congenital varicella syndrome) is highest whenthe mother develops varicella infection between 13 to 20 weeks.Congenital varicella syndrome occurs in 2% of infants with maternal varicella between 13 and 20weeks of gestation and in 0.4% of infants before 13 weeks of gestation. It is rare after 20 weeks.Congenital varicella syndrome is characterized by cicatricial skin scarring in a zoster-like pattern(zig-zag scarring), and limb hypoplasia (shown below). They can also present with neurologicalabnormalities (microcephaly, cortical atrophy, mental retardation), ophthalmic features(chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, cataract), and renal and autonomic system abnormalities(hydronephrosis, neurogenic bladder). Low birth weight is also common.Infants born to mothers with varicella in the period from 5 days prior to delivery up to 2 daysafter delivery are at high risk for severe neonatal varicella. They acquire the infectiontransplacentally.Since the mother has not developed a strong antibody response, the infant lacks the protectiveeffect of maternal anti-varicella-zoster virus (VZV) antibodies. Therefore varicella-zoster immuneglobulin (VZIG) should be administered as soon as possible after birth to newborns whosemothers have varicella 5 days before and up to 2 days after the delivery.Since perinatally acquired varicella can be potentially life-threatening, the infant should typicallybe treated with intravenous acyclovir (10 mg/kg every 8 hours) when lesions appear.For pregnant women with uncomplicated primary varicella or herpes zoster that does not requirehospitalization, the recommended treatment is oral acyclovir (800 mg five times daily for sevendays).548
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: A young woman delivered a baby with limb hypoplasia and cicatricial skin lesions. Which ofthe following infections did the mother most likely have during her pregnancy?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of congenital varicella syndrome. It is seen in babies born tomothers who had chickenpox infections during their pregnancy.Features of congenital varicella syndrome include:• Chorioretinitis•Limb hypoplasia• Cicatricial skin lesions• Microphthalmia• Cerebral cortical atrophy• Growth restriction•• HydronephrosisThe image below shows limb hypoplasia in fetal varicella syndrome:549
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: In a pregnant woman with syphilis, the infection can get transmitted to the fetus duringwhich stage in pregnancy?
questions.explanation: A pregnant woman with syphilis can transmit T. pallidum to the fetus at 10-15 weeks of gestation.Features of congenital syphilis include:• Hutchinson's triad - It is seen in late congenital syphilis.•⚫ Hutchinson's teeth small widely spaced, peg-shaped, notched upper incisors• Interstitial keratitis• Sensorineural hearing loss••Mulberry molarsRhagades deep fissuring of mucocutaneous junctions in the nares, lips, and anus-• Frontal bossingSaber shins anterior tibial bowing-• Clutton's joints - painless, symmetric hydrarthrosis of the knees and elbowsThe image below shows Hutchinson incisors.550Note: The risk of fetal infection during untreated early maternal syphilis is ~75-95%, decreasingto ~35% for maternal syphilis of >2 years duration.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: You are posted in the labor room. While inspecting the placenta to rule out anyabnormalities, you notice that it appears pale and enlarged. Which of the following infectionsdoes the mother most likely have?
questions.explanation: Enlarged and pale placenta is due to infection by syphilis.Other clinical manifestations and complications include:• Spontaneous abortion• Stillbirth• Non-immune hydrops•• Intrauterine growth restriction• Perinatal death.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: A sexually active woman presents with amenorrhea for the past 3 months and a history of apainless genital ulcer. UPT is positive and routine antenatal tests revealed a reactive VDRLreport. What is the dose of benzathine penicillin that should be given for this patient?

options.B: 2.4 million units intramuscularly as a single injection
options.C: 2.4 million units intramuscularly daily, plus probenecid 500 mg orally for 14 days.
options.D: 2.4 million units intramuscularly weekly for three doses

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of early syphilis in a pregnant woman. 2.4 million units ofbenzathine penicillin should be given intramuscularly as a single injection.Treatment of syphilis includes:• Early syphilis - Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly as a single injection•• Late syphilis (>1 year duration) - Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularlyweekly for three dosesTreatment of neurosyphilis:•• Aqueous crystalline penicillin G, 3–4 million units intravenously every 4 hours for 10–14 days551• Procaine penicillin, 2.4 million units intramuscularly daily, plus probenecid 500 mg orally fourtimes daily, both for 10-14 days.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: A woman at 24 weeks of gestation presented with complaints of fatigue, joint pain, and thefollowing rash for 3 weeks. Urinalysis showed proteinuria and anti-Smith antibodies werepositive. Which of the following complications is least likely in this patient?538
questions.explanation: The above scenario points to a diagnosis of SLE. Preterm labor is a complication in pregnantwomen with SLE, not post-term delivery.Complications in a pregnant patient with SLE include:• Thrombophilia• Preterm labor•Hypertension, eclampsia, and preeclampsia• Anemia• Thrombocytopenia• Stroke• Renal failureFeatures of neonatal lupus include:•Cardiac abnormalities - Complete heart blocks•Cutaneous lupus• Hepatobiliary diseases - liver failure, transient conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, transienttransaminase elevations• Hematologic abnormalities - thrombocytopenia, neutropenia, or anemia
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: A woman with HIV presents for a routine antenatal checkup at 35 weeks of gestation.Investigations revealed a viral load of >1000 copies/ml. What will be the best mode ofdelivery in this patient?
questions.explanation: Cesarean delivery is the preferred mode of delivery in a woman with HIV viral load above 1000copies/ml at 34-36 weeks of gestation.Cesarean delivery is usually scheduled at 38 weeks of gestation, or two weeks before the due date.Pregnant women with HIV on ART throughout pregnancy, with a viral load <1000copies/mL evaluated within 4-6 weeks of delivery, may choose to have a vaginal delivery.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: A woman is diagnosed to be positive for HIV in her first trimester. What is the appropriatemanagement?

options.A: Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery
options.B: Start ART after 1st trimester and continue life-long
options.C: Start ART immediately and continue life-long539
options.D: Start ART after 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery

questions.explanation: ART should be initiated immediately and continued lifelong in all pregnant and breastfeedingwomen with HIV. This is regardless of their WHO clinical stage and CD4 cell count.*Note: Pearl attached below has been updated according to the NACO ART guidelines 2021.Efavirenz has been replaced by Dolutegravir as per the new guidelines.552
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: A woman with HIV on antiretroviral therapy is in labor. Which of the following will be givento her newborn baby prophylactically?

options.C: 12 weeks of zidovudine, nevirapine and lamivudine

questions.explanation: In India, according to the NACO guidelines, nevirapine is given in the syrup form for 6 weeks toan infant of a mother who is on long-term ART.In infants born to mothers with HIV who are not on ART, syrup nevirapine should be continuedfor 12 weeks.According to the NIH guidelines, zidovudine should be given to the neonate for 4 weeks.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: The risk of developing a stroke is highest during what period of gestation in a pregnantwoman?
questions.explanation: The highest incidence of stroke in pregnancy is 5 days to 2 weeks postpartum. This is followed bythe intrapartum period.There is an increased risk of cerebrovascular thrombosis post-delivery due to a sudden reductionin the blood volume, a fall in the level of circulating antithrombotic factors, and venous stasis.Risk factors of stroke in pregnancy include:•Hypertensive disorders•Gestational diabetes• Antepartum hemorrhage• Cesarean delivery.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding epilepsy in pregnancy?

options.A: It increases risk of fetal malformations by 5%
options.B: Seizure risk is more at the time of delivery
options.C: Seizure frequency increases in 30% of women
options.D: Ideal contraceptive in breast feeding mother with seizure disorder is DMPA

questions.explanation: Untreated epilepsy has no association with fetal malformations. Anti-epileptic medications suchas valproate, phenytoin, etc., are responsible for fetal malformations.Seizure frequency is unchanged in 50%, increased in 30%, and decreased in 20% women.Seizure risk increases during labor as pain and hyperventilation decrease the seizure threshold.The ideal contraceptive in a breastfeeding mother with a seizure disorder is depotmedroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA), as progestins increase the seizure threshold.553
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy
